text: Which President was unanimously elected from 1732-1799?
Who was the only President in US history to hold the job of a hangman?
Who was the only tailor ever to be President?
Which President never lived in the White House?
Which President never represented a political party?
Who was the first president to be inaugurated in Washington DC?
Who was the only President to be elected for two non-consecutive terms?
Name the first US President born in the United States, after the American Revolution.
Who was the only President to serve in both WWI and WWII?
Who was the first ever President to visit all 50 states?
Who was the only President to resign?
Which US President was also a licensed bartender?
Which four Vice Presidents were elected to President in the next consecutive term?
options: John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Martin Van Buren, and George H. W. Bush
Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Walter Mondale, and George W. Bush
John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, Hubert Humphrey, and Al Gore
Harry S. Truman, Richard Nixon, Lyndon B. Johnson, and GeraldFord
answer: John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Martin Van Buren, and George H. W. Bush

text: Name the only presidential candidate that was not a Mason in the 1860 election.
Who was the only President who was a lifelong bachelor?
Who wrote 'The Life and Morals Of Jesus Of Nazareth'?
Who was the lightest President of the United States?
Who made the shortest inauguration speech on record, at 133 words and less than two minutes long?
Which former United States President holds the record for the longest inauguration speech in history, at 8,578 words long?
Which President held the shortest Presidency on record?
What was Gerald Rudolph Ford's name before he was adopted?
Who became the youngest President at age 42?
Which three presidents died on 4 July?
options: Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, and James Monroe
George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and Andrew Jackson
James Madison, John Quincy Adams, and Martin Van Buren
James Buchanan, Ulysses S. Grant, and Rutherford B. Hayes
answer: Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, and James Monroe
